Sénégal – Projet d’irrigation de
            Debi-Lampsar : Sénégal - Projet d’irrigation de Debi - Lampsar

docna.cdata!: Senegal - Projet d'irrigation de Debi - Lampsar

subtopic: Crops and Crop Management Systems,Environmental Economics & Policies,Economic Theory & Research,Drylands & Desertification,Agricultural Research

0.cdata!:
Senegal - Projet d'irrigation de
            Debi - Lampsar

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Debi - Lampsar
            Irrigation Project for Senegal are to develop irrigation on
            1100 ha at Debi and 2200 ha at Lampsar, to benefit some 1100
            farmers and their families. Project construction began in
            January, 1979, after a delay of almost a year caused by
            management changes at the implementing agency and
            difficulties in finalizing the works supervision contract.
            While most of the originally foreseen project components
            were completed well before the intended final closing date
            of June 30, 1983, this was extended several times to permit
            disbursement on added components including creation of small
            village perimeters and rehabilitation of the Savoigne
            perimeter and canal. Final disbursement and the eventual
            closing date occurred on October 29, 1986. The originally
            designated net area for irrigation could not be fully
            developed because of excessively saline and sandy soils
            encountered, and because of a denser network of canals and
            dikes that resulted from shifting from 3 ha to about 1 ha
            farm allocations. Over 20 percent of the appraised area was
            thus lost, although this was partially compensated for by
            development of other perimeters that were added to the
            project. Production of tomatoes was abandoned after
            difficulties with the first crop showed that the project
            soils were too heavy and saline for remunerative yields.
